Saratoga.bias_notes: The Graveyard of Champions. Fair track overall but rail position matters. Late in meet can become deep and favor closers.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Check rail position daily. 18+ feet can favor speed.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Long stretch allows closers but honest pace required.

Belmont_Park.bias_notes: Big Sandy. Large circumference means fair track. Closers can win from anywhere.

handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Closers love Belmont. Even sprints allow come-from-behind wins.

Gulfstream_Park.bias_notes: THE SPEED TRACK. 6F sprints are Wire-to-Wire dominated. Golden Rail is common.

handicapping_angles.dirt_sprints: 6F races are dominated by the lead horse.
handicapping_angles.one_turn_mile: Post 1 is disadvantaged; Posts 3-6 are ideal.

Santa_Anita.bias_notes: Dirt track can get very hard and fast. When 'sealed' (wet), it moves up inside speed significantly.

Del_Mar.bias_notes: Short stretch. Speed/Pressers favored on dirt. Turf is narrow and firm.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed has slight edge due to one-mile configuration.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: Inside posts slight advantage on turf.

Churchill_Downs.bias_notes: Home of the Derby. Track plays relatively fair due to longer stretch.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Generally fair. Long stretch allows closers.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Derby/Oaks fields create chaos. Favors stalkers.

Keeneland.bias_notes: Short stretch means speed can steal. Rail position critical.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias due to short stretch.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: Excellent turf. Inside posts slight advantage.

Oaklawn_Park.bias_notes: Track plays fair - can develop speed or closer bias depending on maintenance.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Generally fair but check patterns.

Fair_Grounds.bias_notes: Deep, tiring track. Extremely long stretch. Closers have a fair chance.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Can be deep and tiring - stamina matters.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: Wide turf course, favors late kicks.

Tampa_Bay_Downs.bias_notes: One-mile track but plays fairer than most. Sandy surface.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Fairer than typical one-mile track but speed still has edge.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: Smaller turf but well-maintained. Inside posts advantage.

Parx_Racing.bias_notes: One-mile track with sharp turns. Speed bias exists. Inside posts have significant edge.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias, especially sprint distances. Inside posts dominant.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Get the lead or sit right behind.

Monmouth_Park.bias_notes: The Shore. Generally fair track. Haskell attracts elite 3YOs.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Generally fair to slight speed favor.

Laurel_Park.bias_notes: Maryland's primary track. Fair track overall.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Generally fair but can develop speed bias.

Woodbine.bias_notes: Premier Synthetic track. Tapeta surface plays fair but favors closers/stalkers more than dirt.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Synthetic favors horses who can sustain a run. Late kick is vital.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: E.P. Taylor Turf Course is massive (1.5 miles) - very fair.

Kentucky_Downs.bias_notes: Unique European-style course with elevation changes. NO DIRT.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Unique course - experience matters enormously.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Horses need to rate and handle the hills. Closers often thrive.

Colonial_Downs.bias_notes: Huge dirt track (1.25 miles), massive turf course. Very fair.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Large track = fair track.
handicapping_angles.turf_notes: Secretariat Turf Course is widest in country.

Horseshoe_Indianapolis.bias_notes: Fairer than many regional ovals. Strong IN-bred program.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Generally fair.

Hawthorne.bias_notes: Long stretch makes it one of the fairest one-mile tracks. Closers can get there.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Fairer than typical one-mile due to long stretch.

Emerald_Downs.bias_notes: Pacific Northwest. Speed bias - inside posts advantage.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias on dirt.

Turf_Paradise.bias_notes: Desert track. Speed bias on dirt. Turf course is tight.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias - inside posts advantage.

Sunland_Park.bias_notes: Border track. Speed bias. Sunland Derby is key prep.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias on one-mile track.
Speed bias.

Delta_Downs.bias_notes: THE BULLRING. 6-furlong oval. Extreme speed bias. Inside posts are critical.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: EXTREME speed bias. If you aren't in front or 2nd, you lose.

Penn_National.bias_notes: Night racing. Speed bias - inside posts advantage.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias on dirt.

Finger_Lakes.bias_notes: Upstate NY bullring. Strong speed bias. Inside posts critical.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Strong speed bias. Inside posts dominate.

Thistledown.bias_notes: Cleveland. Speed bias - inside posts advantage.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed bias - inside posts advantage.

Belterra_Park.bias_notes: River downs. Speed favors on dirt. Small turf favors inside.

handicapping_angles.surface_bias: Speed favors on dirt.

Royal_Randwick.bias_notes: Two tracks: Kensington (inner) and Course Proper. Course Proper is fair with 'The Rise'. Kensington favors on-pace.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Course Proper is fair. Kensington favors on-pace.

Nowra.bias_notes: A spacious South Coast country track featuring a long 400m home straight with a slight uphill gradient. It is generally considered a very fair galloping surface.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair. The long, uphill straight gives backmarkers plenty of time to wind up and heavily tests the stamina of front-runners.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside draws are an advantage from the 1000m sprint start due to a relatively short run to the first turn. The 1400m and 1600m starts are much more forgiving.

Rosehill_Gardens.bias_notes: Premier 'On-Pace' track despite long straight. Specialists thrive here.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Moderate on-pace bias.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers advantaged in sprints.

Canterbury_Park.bias_notes: SMALL TRACK. Extreme leader bias. Jump and Run tactics essential.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: STRONG LEADER BIAS. Night racing.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: CRITICAL - inside barriers advantage.

Esperance.bias_notes: A coastal WA regional track featuring a tight layout and a short home straight. It plays very much as a 'horses for courses' track where local specialists thrive.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias. The short run home makes it very difficult for backmarkers to swoop and win.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are highly advantageous, particularly in sprint races (1100m - 1200m).

Warwick_Farm.bias_notes: Mid-size track. Triangular shape. On-pace bias.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Moderate on-pace bias.

Hawkesbury.bias_notes: A premier provincial circuit that often attracts elite Sydney metro stables. It is a spacious, galloping track with a 380m straight that runs slightly uphill to the finish.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair track. The long, uphill straight gives backmarkers plenty of time to swoop, but it will severely test the fitness of front-runners.
handicapping_angles.class_factor: Sydney metropolitan form lines are very strong here. Don't treat it like a standard 'country' track.
handicapping_angles.chute_starts: The 1000m and 1300m starts are in chutes, providing long, straight runs to the first turn, negating wide barriers.

Kingscote.bias_notes: Home of the famous Kangaroo Island Cup. It is a unique country circuit with a relatively tight circumference (1500m). Because of the tight turns and shorter straight, it generally favors horses that race on or near the speed.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias. Horses drawn wide who have to go back early often find it too difficult to make up ground.
handicapping_angles.local_knowledge: Mainland trainers targeting the carnival often bring horses specifically suited for tight tracks. Look for tactical speed and agility.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are a distinct advantage across most distances.

Geraldton.bias_notes: A spacious regional track featuring a long 400m home straight. It is generally a very fair galloping track where every horse gets a chance, but strong coastal winds can completely dictate the pattern of the day.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Inherently fair due to the long straight, allowing backmarkers plenty of time to wind up.
handicapping_angles.wind_factor: CRITICAL. A strong headwind in the straight will stop leaders in their tracks and heavily favor swoopers. A tailwind makes front-runners very hard to catch.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Relatively fair, though inside draws are preferred from the 1100m sprint start.

Canberra.bias_notes: Thoroughbred Park features two tracks. The Course Proper (Turf) is a spacious, fair track with a 400m straight. The Acton Track (Synthetic) is used primarily in winter and often favors horses racing on the pace.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Turf: Very fair, allows swoopers. Synthetic (Acton): Often favors on-pace runners and inside draws.
handicapping_angles.surface: Always check if the meeting is on the Acton track, as synthetic form does not always translate to turf.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are highly advantageous on the Acton track, but less critical on the main Turf course.

Newcastle.bias_notes: Huge, spacious track. Very fair. Form translates to Randwick.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair. Closers competitive.

Goulburn.bias_notes: The 'Randwick of the South'. Big, spacious, fair. Sydney stables dominate.

handicapping_angles.tempo: Long straight allows backmarkers to swoop.

Quirindi.bias_notes: A challenging, undulating country track with tight turns. However, it features a long 400m home straight that gives backmarkers plenty of room to wind up.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Relatively fair. While the tight corners help on-pace runners save ground, the long straight ensures swoopers get their chance.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Wide draws are a notable disadvantage from the 1400m start due to the track layout.

Seymour.bias_notes: A very spacious and wide track that underwent a major surface rebuild in recent years. With broad, sweeping turns and a generous 380m straight, it is known as a premium, fair galloping track.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair. The wide track layout allows every horse to get their chance. Backmarkers have plenty of time and room to swoop.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Relatively fair across all distances due to the wide circuit and long runs into the turns.

Terang.bias_notes: A spacious country track with sweeping turns and a generous 400m home straight. The long run home features a slight uphill gradient, making it a genuine stamina test.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair track. The long, uphill straight gives backmarkers plenty of time to wind up and swoop, while heavily testing the fitness of front-runners.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Relatively fair across most distances due to the wide track and generous runs into the turns.

Kembla_Grange.bias_notes: Sister track to Randwick (identical dimensions). Long straight.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Slight on-pace but fair.
Moderate on-pace bias.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers advantage.

Taree.bias_notes: Tight turning track. On-pace runners have an advantage, especially with the rail out.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Favor leaders and horses drawing inside.

Mackay.bias_notes: A tight North Queensland provincial circuit with a short 310m home straight. The track layout heavily favors horses that can position themselves on the speed before the turn.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias. It is very difficult to make up significant ground from the back of the field here.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are highly advantageous, especially from the 1050m and 1100m sprint starts.

Tamworth.bias_notes: A premier country track in NSW known for being spacious and very fair. The 380m straight allows backmarkers plenty of time to wind up.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair. While tactical speed is always helpful in the country, swoopers are highly effective here.
handicapping_angles.chute_starts: The 1200m and 1400m starts provide long runs into the first turn, which heavily reduces the penalty for drawing wide barriers.

Bathurst.bias_notes: The Billy Souaud Track. Fair surface with a decent straight. Backmarkers get their chance.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fairer than most country tracks.

Sapphire_Coast.bias_notes: Spacious country track with a long straight. Gives all runners a chance, but leaders can be hard to catch if pace is slow.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair track. Long straight suits swoopers.

Murwillumbah.bias_notes: Country track. Can be tight and favors on-pace runners. Leaders often hard to run down.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias, especially when rail is out.

Dubbo.bias_notes: Country track with a short straight. Leaders and on-pace runners have a distinct advantage. Difficult to make ground from the back.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias due to short straight.

Grafton.bias_notes: July Carnival venue. Generally fair track, but can favor on-pace when rail is out. Good drainage.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair, but watch rail placement.

Flemington.bias_notes: Headquarters. Wide, sweeping turns. Swoopers paradise. 1200m Straight Six is unique.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: VERY FAIR. Closers love Flemington.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Less critical due to long straight.

Moonee_Valley.bias_notes: The Saucer. Tightest metro track. CRITICAL LEADER BIAS.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: EXTREME ON-PACE BIAS. Must be forward.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: CRITICAL - inside barriers gold.

Caulfield.bias_notes: Triangular shape. On-pace bias but closers can win with momentum.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Moderate on-pace bias.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers advantage.

Moe.bias_notes: A spacious Gippsland track with wide turns and a 300m home straight. Its most defining characteristic is the winter weather—Moe is famous for holding meetings on genuinely Heavy, taxing surfaces.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Plays relatively fair on Good/Soft surfaces. However, when the track gets Heavy, the inside rail often 'chops out', and horses will fan wide into the straight looking for better going.
handicapping_angles.wet_track_notes: Upgrade horses with proven Heavy track form (genuine 'mudlarks'). Fitness is severely tested here in the winter.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Fair across most distances, though you don't want to be caught 3-wide without cover around the broad turns.

Sandown.bias_notes: Two tracks: Hillside (fairer) and Lakeside (tighter). Hillside favors stayers.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Hillside: Fair/Closer. Lakeside: On-pace.

Cranbourne.bias_notes: Large, spacious track but long turns can trap horses wide. Night racing venue.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair, but on-pace favored when rail is out.

Kilmore.bias_notes: An undulating, challenging country track. The back straight dips down, but the 320m home straight is a tough uphill run. 'Only good horses win at Kilmore' is a local saying because of the stamina required.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: The uphill finish tests weak leaders. Horses need genuine stamina to hold on here.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Wide draws are a significant disadvantage from the 1600m start due to the quick run into the first turn.

Clare.bias_notes: A picturesque provincial track in South Australia. It is a relatively tight circuit that generally favors horses racing prominently. Very much a 'horses for courses' venue.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias is prevalent due to the tight nature of the track.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are an advantage, especially in the shorter sprint races.

Kyneton.bias_notes: Tight track with a short straight. Leaders and on-pace runners have a significant advantage.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers critical due to tight turns.

Port_Macquarie.bias_notes: A coastal provincial track with a 1600m circumference. It is a relatively flat track with tighter turns, meaning horses that can position themselves on or near the speed often have a tactical advantage.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Slight on-pace bias due to the tighter corners, though the 340m straight gives backmarkers a fair chance if the tempo is genuine.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers are advantageous from the 1000m and 1100m starts due to the short run to the first turn.
handicapping_angles.weather: Being a coastal track, it can receive heavy rainfall. When the track is rated Heavy, look for proven 'mudlarks' and wide runners as the inside section can chop out.

Sale.bias_notes: Greenwattle Racecourse. Generally a fair and galloping track. One of the better country surfaces in Victoria.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair track. Gives backmarkers a chance.

Eagle_Farm.bias_notes: Spacious and fair. Drains rapidly. Favors runners getting off the fence.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair. Closers can feature.
On-pace bias. Inside barriers advantage.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Critical.

Rockhampton.bias_notes: Callaghan Park features one of the longest straights in Australia (600m). While this gives backmarkers plenty of time to wind up, free-rolling leaders who kick early on the turn can be surprisingly hard to run down.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair due to the long straight, but on-pace runners are still dangerous on dry tracks.
handicapping_angles.wet_track_notes: On Soft/Heavy tracks, the inside often chops out; look for horses swooping down the outside rail.
handicapping_angles.long_straight: Patience is key for jockeys. Moves made too early often fail.

Gatton.bias_notes: The 'Lockyer Valley' track. Notoriously tight with a short straight (300m). Features unique distances like 860m. Extreme leader bias in sprints.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: LEADER DOMINATED. 860m & 1100m races are rarely won from the back. Rail position exacerbates this.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers (1-4) are gold. Wide gates in sprints are a 'coffin corner'.
handicapping_angles.specific_distance: 860m is a specialist distance - look for pure speed.

Wyong.bias_notes: Tight, turning track with a very short straight (280m). Often compared to Moonee Valley for its 'saucer' shape. Favors on-pace runners heavily.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias. Difficult to swoop from the back unless tempo is suicidal.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside draws are critical, especially from the 1000m-1350m starts.
handicapping_angles.distance_notes: 1350m start has a long back straight run but the first turn comes up quickly.

Lismore.bias_notes: A tight, turning track often affected by rain (Northern Rivers region). It generally favors on-pace runners who can handle the turns. The surface can deteriorate quickly to Soft/Heavy.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias is common. Leaders are difficult to run down if they corner well.
handicapping_angles.wet_track_notes: Check the weather. Lismore is frequently Heavy, and 'swimmers' (mudlarks) excel here.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside draws are an advantage due to the tight turns.

Gold_Coast.bias_notes: Tight track. Magic Millions venue. On-pace bias.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside critical.

Dalby.bias_notes: Tight country circuit. Leaders track, especially over short trips.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Speed bias is significant.

Ipswich.bias_notes: The 'Eye Liner' track. Notoriously tight with a short straight. Leaders often win.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong leader bias. Difficult to swoop from the back.

Sunshine_Coast.bias_notes: Corbould Park. Big, spacious, galloping track. Very fair. Also has a Polytrack (synthetic).

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair. Large track allows horses time to wind up.
handicapping_angles.polytrack_notes: Check surface - Polytrack form can differ from Turf.

Townsville.bias_notes: Provincial track. Sweeping turns but short home straight. On-pace runners often hold on.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias. Difficult to swoop late.

Ascot.bias_notes: Uphill straight tests stamina. 'Fremantle Doctor' wind aids leaders.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair but speed has edge.
handicapping_angles.isolation_notes: WA form lines distinct from East Coast.

Bunbury.bias_notes: A tighter, provincial circuit compared to Ascot. The short 320m straight means on-pace runners are favored. It can be difficult to make up ground from the back unless the pace is frantic.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias is common. Leaders often kick on the turn.
handicapping_angles.wind_factor: Like Ascot, the 'Doctor' sea breeze can impact races later in the day, but the shorter straight mitigates it somewhat.
handicapping_angles.surface: Generally firm and fast in summer.

Belmont_Park_WA.bias_notes: Winter track. Handles wet well. Fairer than Ascot.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Slight on-pace bias.

Morphettville.bias_notes: Two tracks: Main and Parks. Main track is fair and spacious. Parks track is tighter and favors on-pace runners.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Main: Fair. Parks: On-pace/Inside.
handicapping_angles.rail_position: Rail out on Parks track exacerbates leader bias.

Gawler.bias_notes: Undulating track with a slight uphill run home. Generally favors on-pace runners and horses drawn well.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Moderate on-pace bias. The uphill straight can test weak front-runners.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside draws are an advantage, particularly from the 1100m and 1200m starts.

Pakenham.bias_notes: A modern, wide track with a massive 480m straight (one of the longest in Victoria). It is widely considered one of the fairest tracks in the state. Every horse gets a chance, and momentum is key.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely Fair. Leaders can win if rated well, but swoopers love the long straight.
handicapping_angles.night_racing: Major venue for Thursday night racing. Patterns can emerge under lights, but generally remains fair.
handicapping_angles.synthetic_note: Note: Pakenham also has a Synthetic track. If the meeting is on 'Synthetic', favor on-pace runners slightly more.

Launceston.bias_notes: Night racing venue. Short straight makes it hard to make up ground from the back.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong on-pace bias due to short straight.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside draws essential.

Sha_Tin.bias_notes: Generally FAIR. 430m straight allows closers. Rail position (A, B, C courses) moves and significantly affects bias. AWT favors on-pace.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Turf: Fair. AWT: On-pace/Inner.
handicapping_angles.rail_position: CRITICAL. A course = tightest. C course = widest.
handicapping_angles.class_factor: Class system is rigid. Class 1 is elite.

Happy_Valley.bias_notes: TIGHT TRACK with SHORT STRAIGHT. Strong on-pace/leader bias. Inside barriers critical.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: STRONG ON-PACE BIAS. Must be forward.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: CRITICAL - Inside barriers (1-4) dominate.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Deep closers have almost no chance.

Tokyo_Racecourse.bias_notes: VERY FAIR track - longest straight in Japan. Closers can win from anywhere. Japan Cup venue.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Very fair. Closers love Tokyo.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Genuinely run races allow closers to reel in leaders.

Nakayama_Racecourse.bias_notes: TIGHT TRACK with SHORT STRAIGHT. Strong on-pace bias compared to Tokyo. Uphill finish.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: On-pace bias. Uphill finish tests stamina.
handicapping_angles.barrier_draw: Inside barriers favored.

Funabashi.bias_notes: Famous for its unique 'Spiral Turn' design. The curves are banked to allow horses to maintain full momentum while cornering. This makes it one of the fairest NAR dirt tracks—closers can actually swoop from the outside here.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fairer than most dirt tracks due to the spiral turn. Outside swoopers are viable.
handicapping_angles.surface: Deep sand (NAR standard). Requires significant stamina/power.
handicapping_angles.spiral_turn: Don't be afraid of horses drawn wide; they can carry speed through the turn without drifting wide.

Tokyo_City_Keiba_Ohi.bias_notes: Also known as 'Ohi'. Night racing. Exclusively DIRT (Deep Sand). NAR racing (Local). Requires power.

handicapping_angles.kickback: Sand kickback is severe. Horses on rail suffer. Outside draws (tactical speed) often better.
handicapping_angles.pedigree: Ignore Turf form. Look for 'Dirt' sires.
handicapping_angles.track_bias: Dirt racing - on-pace typically favored but kickback avoidance is key.

Kawasaki.bias_notes: A very tight, flat dirt oval with extremely sharp turns and a short home straight (300m). The surface is often deep/heavy sand.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extreme advantage to leaders and stalkers. It is very difficult to make up ground from the back due to the tight turns and short straight.
handicapping_angles.kickback: Kickback is severe. Horses stuck on the rail behind a wall of dirt often quit. Outside draws (stalking position) are often better than inside draws if the horse lacks early speed.
handicapping_angles.cornering: The turns are sharper than JRA tracks. Horses must be agile; long-striding types often struggle to corner smoothly here.

Meydan.bias_notes: World-class venue. Dubai World Cup Night ($35M). Generally fair tracks.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Turf: Fair. Dirt: Can favor speed but fair overall.

King_Abdulaziz_Racecourse.bias_notes: Host of the Saudi Cup ($20M). Both surfaces. Major February meeting.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Dirt: Fair with long straight. Speed slight edge.
handicapping_angles.saudi_cup_notes: Saudi Cup (1800m dirt) favors tactical speed.

Busan.bias_notes: Left-handed. Sand surface. Long straight allows closers, but kickback is significant.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Sand track. Power runners preferred.
handicapping_angles.kickback: Avoid horses stuck on the rail behind leaders.

Ascot.bias_notes: STIFF UPHILL FINISH. Straight course (5f-1m) fair. Round course has sweeping bends.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Uphill finish demands stamina. High draws favored on soft ground (Straight).

Epsom_Downs.bias_notes: UNIQUE - Horseshoe shaped, severe camber, downhill into Tattenham Corner. Agility matters.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: LOW DRAWS FAVORED. Horses must handle camber.

Newmarket.bias_notes: Rowley Mile (Spring/Autumn) and July Course. Wide, galloping, fair.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: The Dip can catch horses out. High draws often favored in big fields.

York.bias_notes: The Knavesmire. Very flat, wide, galloping. Fairest track in UK.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair. Best horse wins.

Goodwood.bias_notes: Undulating, tricky. Downhill sections. Not fair - specialists thrive.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Low draws favored. Balance essential.

Wolverhampton.bias_notes: Tight AW track. Short straight. Kickback issues.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Low draws advantage in sprints. Handy horses preferred.

Lingfield_Park.bias_notes: The AW track is sharp and undulating with a famous downhill run into the home straight. Momentum is everything—horses must be balanced. The Turf track is also sharp and tests handling.

handicapping_angles.track_bias_aw: Sharp turns favor handy horses. The downhill run into the straight creates a 'slingshot' effect—closers must get moving *before* the turn.
handicapping_angles.draw_bias: Low draws (1-4) strongly favored in sprints (5f-6f) on the AW. Wide draws are a death sentence in short races.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Tactical speed is king. Slow starters often get trapped behind horses struggling with the downhill gradient.

Chelmsford_City.bias_notes: A wide, galloping track with sweeping bends (formerly Great Leighs). Despite its width, it is notoriously favorable to front-runners and horses racing prominently.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Strong 'Prominent' bias. It is surprisingly difficult to come from behind here, likely due to kickback severity. Leaders often don't stop.
handicapping_angles.kickback: Severe kickback. Horses buried in the pack often resent it and spit the bit.
handicapping_angles.draw_bias: Fairer than Lingfield due to wide bends, but you do not want to be posted 3-wide facing the breeze.

Southwell.bias_notes: Recently converted to Tapeta. Galloping AW track.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fairer than Wolverhampton.

Kempton_Park.bias_notes: Right-handed AW. Fairer than Lingfield but speed handy.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: High draw disadvantage in routes.

The_Curragh.bias_notes: HQ of Irish racing. Wide, galloping, fair. All 5 Classics run here.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Very fair. Best horse wins.

Leopardstown.bias_notes: Premier dual-purpose track. Fair galloping nature.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Generally fair.
Low draws advantage. Course specialists.

Longchamp.bias_notes: Grande Piste is fair with long straight. Arc venue. False straight.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Grande Piste: Fair. False straight can deceive.
Generally fair.
Fair. Good straight.

Te_Rapa.bias_notes: Premier Waikato track. Left-handed. Generally fair but sand-based profile drains well.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair, but on-pace in sprint races is good.

Ashburton.bias_notes: A very large, spacious, and flat track in the South Island. It features broad sweeping turns and a long 400m straight, making it one of the fairest galloping tracks in New Zealand.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Extremely fair. Every horse gets their chance here. The long straight allows backmarkers plenty of time to wind up and swoop.
handicapping_angles.surface: Known for draining quite well, often providing firmer footing than other regional tracks during the winter months.
handicapping_angles.chute_starts: The 1200m and 1400m sprint starts offer long, straight runs before the first turn, reducing the penalty of drawing wide.

Manawatu.bias_notes: A rectangular track with uniform turns and a 400m straight. Generally considered a fair, galloping track where every horse gets a chance. The soil is clay-based, so it can get very heavy in winter.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Fair track. In dry conditions, on-pace runners have a slight advantage, but swoopers can win. In the wet (Winter), the fence often goes 'off' and horses will fan wide in the straight.
handicapping_angles.chute_starts: The 1400m and 1600m starts have long runs to the first turn, minimizing draw bias.
handicapping_angles.wet_track_notes: Notorious for deep Heavy tracks in winter. Look for 'mudlarks' and wide runners.

Te_Aroha.bias_notes: A large, spacious track featuring one of New Zealand's longest home straights (500m). Uniquely, there is a downhill run from the 800m to the 400m turn, followed by a testing 3-meter uphill incline in the home straight.

handicapping_angles.track_bias: Despite the massive straight, statistics often show a strong advantage for on-pace runners. The downhill run into the turn allows leaders to steal a march and build cheap momentum.
handicapping_angles.stamina_test: The uphill finish exposes horses that lack true stamina or were used up too early. Weak finishers get swallowed up in the final 100m.
handicapping_angles.wet_track_notes: Frequently races on Soft/Heavy tracks, especially as it is a major venue for the winter jumps season.

Meadowlands.bias_notes: The Big M. Long stretch favors closers. Speed does not hold well.

Yonkers.bias_notes: Speed favor. Hard to win from outside (7 & 8). Passing lane helps pocket sitters.

Northfield_Park.bias_notes: Inside speed bias. 'Flying Turn' helps leaders corner fast.

Mohegan_Sun_Pocono.bias_notes: Compromise track. Speed usually holds but closers can win.

Harrahs_Philadelphia.bias_notes: Similar to Pocono. Speed has slight edge.

Hoosier_Park.bias_notes: Long stretch. Closers have a real chance.

Scioto_Downs.bias_notes: Ohio speed track. Inside posts preferred.

Red_Mile.bias_notes: Clay surface. Very fast. Favors speed/closers with elite turns of foot.

Saratoga_Harness.bias_notes: Classic half-mile speed bias. Inside posts dominate.

Freehold.bias_notes: Classic half-mile speed bias. Posts 1-3 dominate.

Vernon_Downs.bias_notes: Five-eighths provides some closer opportunities but speed dominates class levels.

Batavia_Downs.bias_notes: Western NY half-miler. Standard half-mile speed bias.

Hawthorne_Harness.bias_notes: Five-eighths allows versatile horses to succeed.

Cal_Expo.bias_notes: West Coast harness. Mile configuration favors closers.

Woodbine_Mohawk_Park.bias_notes: Canada's premier harness track. Seven-eighths layout allows both speed and closers. North America Cup is continent's richest race.

handicapping_angles.post_position: Posts 1-5 preferred. Larger circumference makes posts 6-8 more playable than half-milers.
handicapping_angles.pace_scenario: Balanced track. Both front-end speed and closers can win. Look for horses that can close in :26 low quarters.
handicapping_angles.class_drops: Ontario Sire Stakes (OSS) horses are typically well-bred and well-trained. OSS droppers into overnight are live.
handicapping_angles.driver_factor: James MacDonald, Bob McClure, Doug McNair, Sylvain Filion, Jody Jamieson - deep colony of elite reinsmen.
handicapping_angles.track_condition: Well-maintained year-round racing. Handles Canadian weather well with strong drainage.
handicapping_angles.currency_note: Purses in CAD. Convert for comparing class levels to US tracks.

Menangle_Park.bias_notes: Premier track. Big, spacious. Speed holds but closers can swoop.

Tabcorp_Park_Melton.bias_notes: Victoria's HQ. Mobile starts favor speed.

Gloucester_Park.bias_notes: Perth's bullring. Leaders and pocket sitters dominate.

Albion_Park.bias_notes: Brisbane HQ. Passing lane (Sprint Lane) available.

Alexandra_Park.bias_notes: NZ North Island. Smaller track, slight on-pace bias.

Vincennes.bias_notes: Paris. Uphill/Downhill sections. Stamina test. No passing lane.

Solvalla.bias_notes: Sweden. Fast track. Volt starts common.

metadata.notes: Unified database covering Australia, USA, UK, Europe, Asia, and Global Harness with detailed Canadian profiles.
